title: These Crispy Chicken Cutlets Use My Favorite Secret Sauce

Nothing beats these baked crispy hot honey chicken cutlets. With a warm honey-based sauce that’s filled with delicious hints of garlic and slightly spicy notes, this version of crispy chicken cutlets is incredibly satisfying. Even better, they taste like they’ve been fried, but they cook right in the oven. Their crunch comes from a little Parmesan cheese in the breading, which also adds a touch of salt. As the chicken bakes, the cheesy breadcrumb coating becomes nice and toasty. Once dipped in the hot honey sauce, it’s best to serve them right away — alone, with a side, or even between a burger bun. All you need is the oven to get these unbelievably crispy results. The flavorful sauce packs the right amount of heat. It has the ability to still taste delicious without overwhelming the other flavors. And the more you eat, the better it gets.  Key Ingredients in Crispy Hot Honey Baked Chicken Parmesan cheese: Adds crispy bits to the breadcrumb coating, as well as a salty bite and hints of nuttiness. Cayenne pepper: Gives the chicken and sauce a pop of smokiness and some spice that balances the sweetness of the honey. Garlic: Brings out the savory flavor in the honey. Honey: Cuts the garlic’s sharpness, mellowing out the flavor. Panko breadcrumbs: Creates a crunchy exterior that gives the sauce something to hug. Meanwhile, stir 1 1/2 cups panko breadcrumbs, 1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese, 1/4 teaspoon of the kosher salt, 1/4 teaspoon of the black pepper, 1 teaspoon smoked paprika, 1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper, and 1/4 teaspoon onion powder together in a pie plate or small rimmed baking sheet. Whisk 2 large eggs and 1 tablespoon hot sauce together in a medium shallow bowl or pie plate.Cut 2 boneless, skinless chicken breasts in half horizontally so you end up with 4 thin pieces of chicken. Working with 1 piece of chicken at a time, place in a large zip-top bag and pound with a rolling pin or the flat side of a meat mallet until 1/4-inch thick.Season the chicken with the remaining 3/4 teaspoon kosher salt. Bread the chicken 1 piece at a time: Dip into the egg mixture until coated and let the excess drip off. Gently press into the panko mixture until completely coated. Place on a rimmed baking sheet.Bake, flipping halfway through, until the chicken is golden brown and cooked through, about 30 minutes total.A few minutes before the chicken is ready, heat 1/2 cup honey, 2 tablespoons unsalted butter, 3 minced garlic cloves, 1 teaspoon cayenne pepper, 1/2 teaspoon onion powder, and 1 pinch kosher salt in a small skillet over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until simmering. Continue simmering until the sauce is bubbling and fragrant, about 2 minutes. Turn off the heat.Working with 1 piece of chicken at a time, dip in the sauce until completely coated, then place on a serving plate (scrape out any remaining sauce and wash or soak the pan before the sauce solidifies). Garnish with coarsely chopped fresh thyme leaves and flaky salt if desired.Recipe NotesSubstitutions: Store-bought hot honey can be used instead of regular honey. Do not use the cayenne pepper in the sauce.Storage: Leftovers can be refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 3 days.
html:
• Recipes
  • What To Make With
  • Chicken

Crispy Hot Honey Baked Chicken

Janette ZepedaCulinary Producer

I've spent the last 10 years working behind the scenes on some of America's favorite cooking shows, making fun and informative food content, and food styling some really neat cookbooks. I'm a firm believer that cooking and baking should be fun and bring you joy — and never feel like rocket science.

published now

The secret sauce on these chicken cutlets makes them totally irresistible.

Serves4

Prep20 minutes

Cook30 minutes to 35 minutes

We independently select these products—if you buy from one of our links, we may earn a commission. All prices were accurate at the time of publishing.

If there’s a recipe that gets everyone in my family excited for dinner, it’s this one. Nothing beats these baked crispy hot honey chicken cutlets. With a warm honey-based sauce that’s filled with delicious hints of garlic and slightly spicy notes, this version of crispy chicken cutlets is incredibly satisfying. Even better, they taste like they’ve been fried, but they cook right in the oven. Their crunch comes from a little Parmesan cheese in the breading, which also adds a touch of salt. As the chicken bakes, the cheesy breadcrumb coating becomes nice and toasty. Once dipped in the hot honey sauce, it’s best to serve them right away — alone, with a side, or even between a burger bun. Believe me, it makes for a killer chicken sandwich. 

Why You’ll Love It

  • No frying involved. Say goodbye to the days of frying your chicken cutlets! All you need is the oven to get these unbelievably crispy results.
  • The flavorful sauce packs the right amount of heat. It has the ability to still taste delicious without overwhelming the other flavors. And the more you eat, the better it gets. 

Key Ingredients in Crispy Hot Honey Baked Chicken

  • Parmesan cheese: Adds crispy bits to the breadcrumb coating, as well as a salty bite and hints of nuttiness.
  • Cayenne pepper: Gives the chicken and sauce a pop of smokiness and some spice that balances the sweetness of the honey.
  • Garlic: Brings out the savory flavor in the honey.
  • Honey: Cuts the garlic’s sharpness, mellowing out the flavor.
  • Panko breadcrumbs: Creates a crunchy exterior that gives the sauce something to hug.

Comments

The secret sauce on these chicken cutlets makes them totally irresistible.

Nutritional Info

Ingredients

For the chicken:

  • 1 1/2 cups

    panko breadcrumbs

  • 1/4 cup

    grated Parmesan cheese

  • 1 teaspoon

    kosher salt, divided

  • 1/2 teaspoon

    freshly ground black pepper, divided

  • 1 teaspoon

    smoked paprika

  • 1/4 cup

    cayenne pepper

  • 1/4 teaspoon

    onion powder

  • 2

    large eggs

  • 1 tablespoon

    hot sauce, such as Crystal or Tabasco

  • 2

    boneless, skinless chicken breasts (1 to 1 1/2 pounds total)

For the hot honey sauce:

  • 1/2 cup

    honey

  • 2 tablespoons

    unsalted butter

  • 3 cloves

    garlic, minced

  • 1 teaspoon

    cayenne pepper

  • 1/2 teaspoon

    onion powder

  • 1 pinch

    kosher salt

  • Coarsely chopped fresh thyme leaves, for garnish (optional)

  • Flaky salt, for garnish (optional)

  1. Heat the oven to 400ºF. Meanwhile, stir 1 1/2 cups panko breadcrumbs, 1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese, 1/4 teaspoon of the kosher salt, 1/4 teaspoon of the black pepper, 1 teaspoon smoked paprika, 1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper, and 1/4 teaspoon onion powder together in a pie plate or small rimmed baking sheet. Whisk 2 large eggs and 1 tablespoon hot sauce together in a medium shallow bowl or pie plate.

  2. Cut 2 boneless, skinless chicken breasts in half horizontally so you end up with 4 thin pieces of chicken. Working with 1 piece of chicken at a time, place in a large zip-top bag and pound with a rolling pin or the flat side of a meat mallet until 1/4-inch thick.

  3. Season the chicken with the remaining 3/4 teaspoon kosher salt. Bread the chicken 1 piece at a time: Dip into the egg mixture until coated and let the excess drip off. Gently press into the panko mixture until completely coated. Place on a rimmed baking sheet.

  4. Bake, flipping halfway through, until the chicken is golden brown and cooked through, about 30 minutes total.

  5. A few minutes before the chicken is ready, heat 1/2 cup honey, 2 tablespoons unsalted butter, 3 minced garlic cloves, 1 teaspoon cayenne pepper, 1/2 teaspoon onion powder, and 1 pinch kosher salt in a small skillet over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until simmering. Continue simmering until the sauce is bubbling and fragrant, about 2 minutes. Turn off the heat.

  6. Working with 1 piece of chicken at a time, dip in the sauce until completely coated, then place on a serving plate (scrape out any remaining sauce and wash or soak the pan before the sauce solidifies). Garnish with coarsely chopped fresh thyme leaves and flaky salt if desired.

Recipe Notes

Substitutions: Store-bought hot honey can be used instead of regular honey. Do not use the cayenne pepper in the sauce.

Storage: Leftovers can be refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 3 days.
